div.h1: Senior Abby Semelsberger Chooses Marymount Manhattan
div.p: One of the greatest stage performers in Huntington High School’s long history, Abby Semelsberger is only getting started. The senior is headed to Marymount Manhattan College to study musical theater.

a.h2: Sydney Cordeiro Captures Jupiter Hammon Contest Prize
a.p: Sydney Cordeiro loves science and technology, but the Huntington High School sophomore is a wonderful writer, too. The teenager recently won honors in the Town of Huntington African American Historic Designation Council’s Jupiter Hammon essay/poetry contest.

a.h2: Blue Devil Softball Senior Players Reminisce
a.p: They were all set to have their best season ever, but the Huntington High School seniors on the Blue Devil varsity softball team saw everything come to a screeching halt after only four practices.

a.h2: Fab Five Eighth Grade Wrestlers Emerge for Blue Devils
a.p: The Huntington High School varsity wrestling team has traditionally been a veteran laden squad, but last winter the Blue Devils introduced five eighth graders to county opponents and each of them appears well on their way to notable mat success.

a.h2: Senior Brooke Biernacki Chooses Binghamton University
a.p: An exceptionally creative graphic artist, Brooke Biernacki is so good she wants to make a career of it. The Huntington High School senior plans to begin her quest at Binghamton University in the fall after a great four year run that has seen her excel academically, athletically and in the club program.

a.h2: H-ton Fashion Students Adapt and Create Face Masks
a.p: Everyone’s life has been upended in some way by the COVID-19 pandemic that has swept across the globe. Huntington High School students taking fashion design and illustration courses are not exempt from the tumult. But the teenagers are adapting in surprising ways.

a.h2: Huntington High School Recognizes its Distinguished Seniors
a.p: Huntington High School’s top graduating seniors are traditionally honored during a catered dinner in Louis D. Giani Gymnasium. It is a festive evening that typically draws a crowd of more than 300. With the COVID-19 pandemic still raging across the world, the affair won’t be held this year, but officials say the leading scholars in the Class of 2020 are more than deserving of special recognition.

a.h2: Huntington Boys’ Lax Seniors Reminisce on Careers
a.p: When it became clear the Huntington High School boys’ lacrosse team would not be taking the field this year it hit the Blue Devils hard. While they understand the COVID-19 pandemic is serious and only a few miles away people are fighting for their lives, the players and coaches were hoping for a miracle to allow for a shortened season, but it wasn’t meant to be.

a.h2: Senior Neil Jean-Baptiste Chooses University of Delaware
a.p: One of the brightest stars and most colorful and vibrant personalities in Huntington High School’s Class of 2020, Neil Jean-Baptiste is headed to the University of Delaware to study civil engineering.

a.h2: Juniors Study Bacteria’s Effects on Degrading Plastics
a.p: Ryan Aguirre and Kemberlin Hernandez-Veliz have been studying the effect of bacteria on the degradation of certain types of plastic. The juniors are partners on a project they have been pursuing in the science research program at Huntington High School.

a.h2: Freshman Annika Galvin Captures Art Honors
a.p: Annika Galvin is talented. Not only was the Huntington High School freshman among a select group of teenagers to be tapped to participate in this year’s Long Island’s Best Young Artists exhibit at the Heckscher Museum, but she even won an award.

a.h2: Blue Devil Girls’ Lax Seniors Reflect on Careers
a.p: They won’t be able to take the field this spring after Section XI cancelled the season due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the eight Blue Devil girls’ lacrosse team seniors will always remember the time they’ve spent in a Huntington High School uniform and how much their teammates have meant to them through the years.

a.h2: Alice Bradford Chooses University of East Anglia in England
a.p: Alice Bradford was born in England and the Huntington High School senior plans to return to Europe for college. She plans to pursue a degree in biology at the University of East Anglia in preparation for a career as a medical doctor.

a.h2: Huntington Artists in Long Island’s Best Exhibit
a.p: Three Huntington High School student-artists have pieces on display in the Heckscher Museum of Art’s Long Island’s Best Young Artists exhibition this spring.

a.h2: Southdown Navigates Through Challenging Time
a.p: While the country continues to battle the COVID-19 pandemic and Huntington UFSD finds itself in the midst of a distance learning program that the public health crisis has necessitated, the Southdown Primary School community has pulled together and risen to the many challenges that have emerged over the past month.

a.h2: Woodhull School Marches on with Distance Learning
a.p: The Woodhull Intermediate School community has adapted well to the shift to distance learning necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic. While everyone wishes they could be inside the building and engaging in business as usual, teachers and students have worked hard to make the current circumstances as meaningful and successful as possible.

a.h2: Senior Peyton Kalb Chooses University at Albany
a.p: Peyton Kalb has developed a plan for her future and it’s a good one. The Huntington High School senior wants to go into medicine and she has found just the right place to begin her journey. The teenager is excited to begin her studies at the University at Albany.

a.h2: Sophomores Develop Documentary on Walt Disney Animation
a.p: Morgan Colleluori, Alexis Kaloudis and Sophia Toscano knew they wanted to collaborate on a group documentary project for this year’s National History Day initiative, but were unsure of the topic.

a.h2: Sophie Bradford Studies Master WW II Code Breaker
a.p: Sophie Bradford takes her academic studies seriously. So seriously that when the Huntington High School freshman settled on her topic for this year’s National History Day initiative, she traveled to Bletchley Park in Buckinghamshire, England for a closer look at her subject and the famed site where he worked.

a.h2: Jefferson Strives to Keep Students Connected & Supported
a.p: As the battle against the COVID-19 pandemic rages, Jefferson Primary School’s faculty and support staff is striving to keep students there connected and emotionally happy.

a.h2: Senior Izzy Toscano Chooses University of Oklahoma
a.p: Isabella Toscano likes to challenge herself and she’s never afraid to move outside of her comfort zone. The Huntington High School senior wanted something different for college so she will head west to the University of Oklahoma and join the Sooners on one of the most high-spirited campuses in the country.

a.h2: Huntington Photographers are Painting with Light
a.p: The COVID-19 pandemic has necessitated many changes for schools across the country. The Huntington High School photography program has naturally been affected by the transition to remote learning. But the student-photographers and their veteran teacher have been making the best of the situation and continue to push forward with a variety of projects.

a.h2: Sophomore Allison Quinn Develops Unique Documentary
a.p: Allison Quinn wanted to create something special and unique for her National History Day project and the Huntington High School sophomore did just that, winning first place in the competition’s individual documentary category for her short film titled “WASP in WWII: Shattering Gender Stereotypes.”

a.h2: Blue Devil Boys’ Soccer Looks to Fall Season
a.p: The Huntington varsity boys’ soccer team is coming off a 13-3-1 season that saw the Blue Devils win their third league title in five years. Can the magic repeat itself next fall?

a.h2: Senior Ryan Williams Chooses University of Michigan
a.p: Ryan Williams has been in Huntington UFSD’s fold since his first day of kindergarten at Washington Primary School, whose grounds adjoin his backyard. The teenager has excelled academically and athletically and he’s earned many admirers and developed numerous friendships. Now he’s set to study engineering at the University of Michigan.

a.h2: H-ton Duo Participates in Albany Leadership Conference
a.p: Junior Yolani Cabrera and senior Erlyn Flores Reyes might appear to be ordinary, but they are among the most talented and hardworking teenagers in the state. The Huntington High School duo along with many other promising young leaders from around New York participated in the Angelo Del Toro Puerto Rican/Hispanic Youth Leadership Institute in Albany and impressed everyone there.

a.h2: Sophomore Trio Creates Compelling Group Exhibit
a.p: A team of three Huntington High School sophomores researched crusading journalist Nellie Bly and studied how she “shattered the glass ceiling one headline at a time.”

a.h2: Blue Devil Football Waits for Decision on League Placements
a.p: By this time each spring, tentative Suffolk high school football schedules are usually available. That’s not the case this year because of the COVID-19 pandemic. But not to worry Blue Devil fans, it’s only a matter of time.

a.h2: Lily Stein Captures Scholarship to University at Buffalo
a.p: Lily Stein garnered acceptances to some of the best colleges in the country. The Huntington High School senior considered her options before accepting a Presidential Scholarship to attend the University at Buffalo, where she plans to study math and economics.

a.h2: Tied for No. 1 in World, BioSol’s Hopes Are Dashed
a.p: Tied for No. 1 in the world in the Virtual Enterprise International rankings, Huntington High School’s BioSol company had high hopes for the final round of the championships. But the COVID-19 pandemic has led to the cancellation of the competition, much to the disappointment of the teenagers, who are shaking it off and taking it in stride.

a.h2: Huntington Mock Trial Team Looks Ahead
a.p: Huntington sent an extremely experienced and talented team of attorneys and witnesses into the courtroom this year and the Blue Devils finished the regular season with a perfect 4-0 mark. Everyone had high hopes for the playoffs, but the worldwide coronavirus outbreak dashed the hopes of team members.

a.h2: Southdown Boldly Moves into Distance Learning
a.p: Southdown Primary School has moved full speed into the world distance learning on the heels of the COVID-19 pandemic and the closure of school buildings.

a.h2: Huntington Senior Maddie Reed Chooses Bryant University
a.p: Maddie Reed is a remarkable young woman who has enjoyed what can only be called an amazing experience these past four years. The Huntington High School senior has decided to attend Bryant University in Smithfield, Rhode Island, where she plans to study business.

a.h2: Sophomore Erin Ye Studies Bilingualism & Cognitive Function
a.p: Erin Ye isn’t afraid to take on a daunting challenge. The Huntington High School sophomore chose a weighty topic for her science research program project and has spent the past year pursuing it with a sense of tenacity that few teenagers can match.

a.h2: Huntington Music Program is Nationally Recognized
a.p: It never gets old. The Huntington UFSD’s music program was recently named one of the finest in the country and while it has earned that designation before, it remains an exceptional honor and one that the district and community takes a great deal of pride in receiving.

a.h2: Washington School Steps Up for Students
a.p: School buildings might be closed, but Washington Primary School isn’t about to stop presenting awards to its students for a job well done.

a.h2: H-ton Senior John Panos Chooses Northeastern University
a.p: John Panos could already easily pass right now as a businessman. If anyone has the “look” it’s the Huntington High School senior who has excelled in everything he has touched for the past four years. The teenager is headed to Northeastern University in Boston to begin the quest to accomplish his career goals.

a.h2: Sophomore Cassidy Casabona Studies Navajo Code Talkers
a.p: When Cassidy Casabona puts her mind and energy behind accomplishing a goal, the Huntington High School sophomore is unstoppable. She developed an award winning National History Day exhibit on the Navajo code talkers that displayed a depth of research that is rarely seen on the high school level.

a.h2: Freshmen Study Effects of Carbon on Drinking Water Contaminants
a.p: Lauren Gennarelli and Nadeera Ali have been researching the effect of activated carbon on the amount of contaminants in Long Island’s aquifers. The two Huntington freshmen have been pursuing their study in the high school’s science research program.

a.h2: Huntington Highsteppers Happy with Season
a.p: The Huntington Highsteppers are thrilled with the just completed season that saw the high school’s hip dance team place 13th in the Dance Team Union national championships in Orlando, Florida in the pom competition and among the top squads overall.

a.h2: Senior Jaylen Bush to Play Football at Utica College
a.p: Jaylen Bush is headed to Utica College after the Huntington High School senior accepted an invitation to play football for the school in Upstate New York.

a.h2: Henry Stein Studies Social Media’s Effect on Stock Prices
a.p: Henry Stein has some weighty academic interests. The Huntington High School sophomore spent the past year studying the effects of social media and the news on the stock prices of big business.

a.h2: Huntington SEPTA Donates Thousands for Mini-Grants
a.p: The Huntington School District’s Special Education PTA has donated thousands of dollars to the district to cover the cost of ten mini-grant awards for a variety of educational items designed to improve students’ classroom experience.

a.h2: Finley Duo Researches Manhattan Project
a.p: Griffin Kanzer and Nicholas Plachta are two high powered J. Taylor Finley Middle School seventh graders. They have always been outsized achievers, but neither has been resting on his laurels this year. Instead, the duo is reaching new heights.

a.h2: Senior Robert Jean-Gilles Chooses New York University
a.p: Robert Jean-Gilles has a way of commanding a stage. A gifted performer, the Huntington High School senior always seems to rise to the occasion and bring a crowd to its feet. The teenager is a splendid student, too. Soon he will have an opportunity to shine in a much larger arena at New York University in Manhattan.

a.h2: H-ton Photography Students Creating Gallery of Memories
a.p: Schools across the country have transitioned to distance learning models, but Huntington High School photography students are keeping busy at home and creating heartfelt and very honest artwork.

a.h2: Sophomore Teddi Carnesi Wins Honors for Amelia Earhart Project
a.p: Amelia Earhart disappeared over the Pacific Ocean 83 years ago, but she’s still an inspiration for Huntington High School sophomore Teddi Carnesi, who created an award winning historical exhibit covering the life of the flight pioneer.

a.h2: Blue Devil Spring Athletes Play Waiting Game
a.p: The spring season was less than a week old when the order came to cease practices and go into a holding pattern. Huntington High School athletes have been playing a waiting game ever since.

a.h2: Zubair Ali Lands Full Scholarship to Lafayette College
a.p: Zubair Ali’s spectacular run through Huntington High School is ending in fitting fashion; with a full scholarship to Lafayette College as a Marquis Fellow. The senior has excelled in every possible way, including in the performing arts and he has captured the respect of everyone.

a.h2: Huntington Choir Sings Despite School Closure
a.p: There is no place that the vocalists who comprise the Huntington High School chamber choir would rather be than in their rehearsal room with teacher Victoria Garbarino.

a.h2: H-ton Duo Creates Spectacular “West Side Story” Documentary
a.p: Ally Kustera and Emily Roberts have created a spectacular documentary on the artistic power of “West Side Story.” The two Huntington High School sophomores won first place in the local National History Day contest for their nearly 10 minute film and are hoping that despite the COVID-19 pandemic and the school closures now in effect there will be a way for them to showcase their work on the state and national levels.

a.h2: Huntington Students Commemorate Triangle Shirtwaist Tragedy
a.p: The deadly Triangle Shirtwaist Company factory fire occurred decades before Kimberly Schiller was born, but the J. Taylor Finley Middle School English teacher has always made sure her classes are familiar with the event and why it continues to be important today.

a.h2: Huntington Senior RJ Moreno Chooses Elon University
a.p: RJ Moreno has been in no rush. The Huntington High School senior has seen a steady stream of acceptance letters find their way to his mailbox, but he took his time evaluating the possibilities and all of the opportunities before embracing Elon University in North Carolina as the next stop on his journey through life.

a.h2: Huntington Artists on Exhibit at High Arts Showcase
a.p: Seven Huntington High School student-artists are currently exhibiting work at the Huntington Arts Council’s High Arts Showcase XVI at the Main Street Gallery in the village.

a.h2: Huntington Students Examine Juvenile Death Penalty
a.p: Four Huntington High School students researched and analyzed the issue of the death penalty for juveniles in the United States. The group won first place honors in the local National History Day competition.

a.h2: Blue Devil Girls’ Basketball Wins Post-Season Honors
a.p: Abby Maichin, Emily Plachta and Jordan Forte led the Huntington High School varsity girls’ basketball team to the Suffolk Class AA playoffs this past winter.

a.h2: Blue Devil Marching Band Announces New Leadership
a.p: The remarkable sights and sounds and colorful pageantry of the Huntington High School Blue Devil marching band will continue in 2020/21. It’s a tradition traced to the first band in 1934.

a.h2: Junior Grace Wildermuth Studies School Integration on LI
a.p: Grace Wildermuth wanted to engage in meaningful research as she went about developing a project for this year’s National History Day competition. The Huntington High School junior decided to study school integration in Malverne, New York and the nearly 2,500 word paper she wrote won a top award in a very strong field.

a.h2: Student Government Prez Chris Mavrogian’s Favorite Teacher
a.p: Christopher Mavrogian has been in the Huntington UFSD fold since his first day of kindergarten at Washington Primary School. Now he’s a senior. He’s always gotten along well with his teachers, but like just about anyone, he has a faculty favorite.

a.h2: Huntington Guidance Department Ready to Help Students
a.p: Huntington UFSD guidance counselors are just an e-mail away for students and parents who need to reach out for advice and a helping hand regarding school related concerns.

a.h2: Huntington Students Adapt to Distance Learning
a.p: With schools across the state and country ordered to close to fight the COVID-19 pandemic, Huntington UFSD has implemented a distance learning plan to help address the needs of more than 4,500 students enrolled in eight separate buildings across grades K-12.

a.h2: Dynamic Cast for Drama Club’s Crazy for You
a.p: The cast was chosen and rehearsals were underway for the Huntington High School drama club’s spring musical production of the Gershwin’s “Crazy for You.” But the worldwide COVID-19 pandemic brought those preparations to a screeching halt.

a.h2: Huntington Sisters are Tourette’s Youth Ambassadors
a.p: Emily and Charlotte Cheshire are doing amazing work as youth ambassadors with the Tourette Association of America. The sisters are students at Huntington High School, where they have garnered the respect of classmates and faculty members alike.

a.h2: Sophomore Alexis Kaloudis Wins Town Writing Award
a.p: When she learned that she had captured first place honors in the short story category of the Huntington Youth Writes competition, Huntington High School sophomore Alexis Kaloudis was surprised. She didn’t expect to win.
